data: Withholding is the portion of an employee's wages that is not included in their paycheck but is instead remitted directly to the federal, state, or local tax authorities. Withholding reduces the amount of tax employees must pay when they submit their annual tax returns. The employee's income, marital status, number of dependents, and number of jobs all determine the amount withheld.
The portion of an employee's wages or salary that is directly deducted by the employer and sent to the government as an advance payment of income tax.
Withholding is the portion of an employee’s wages that an employer deducts and remits directly to the government as partial payment of the employee’s annual income tax liability.

A quarter is a three-month period on a company's financial calendar that acts as a basis for periodic financial reports and the paying of dividends. A quarter refers to one-fourth of a year and is typically expressed as "Q1â€ for the first quarter, â€œQ2â€ for the second quarter, and so forth. For example, a quarter is often shown with its relevant year, as in Q1 2020 or Q1/20, which represents the first quarter of the year 2020.
A three-month period used for financial reporting and analysis, with Q1 representing January to March, Q2 April to June, Q3 July to September, and Q4 October to December.

A quarter (Q1, Q2, Q3, and Q4) is a three-month period on a company’s financial calendar that acts as a basis for periodic financial reporting and the payment of dividends. Public companies typically report their financial performance at the end of each quarter, with Q1 covering January–March, Q2 April–June, Q3 July–September, and Q4 October–December.
Consumption goods which do not get exhausted immediately but last over a period of time are consumer durables.

Consumer durables are manufactured goods that are not consumed immediately and have a relatively long useful life (typically three years or more). They are purchased by individuals for personal use and include items such as cars, appliances, furniture, and electronics.

Consumer durables are goods purchased by individuals for personal or household use that have a relatively long lifespan, typically lasting three years or more, such as appliances, furniture, and vehicles.

An OPTION SPREAD consisting of a LONG POSITION in a CAP or CALL OPTION and a SHORT POSITION in a FLOOR or PUT OPTION, or vice versa. The sale of one option offsets the PREMIUM payable on the second option, resulting in â€œzero cost.â€ Also known as CYLINDER, RANGE FORWARD, TUNNEL. See also COLLAR.

A zero-cost collar is an options strategy that involves simultaneously buying an out-of-the-money put option and selling an out-of-the-money call option, where the premium received from selling the call option exactly offsets the premium paid for buying the put option. This strategy is used to protect against downside risk while capping potential upside gains, with no net upfront cost.

A zero cost collar is a risk management strategy that involves holding an underlying asset while simultaneously buying a protective put option and selling a covered call option, where the premium received from selling the call offsets the cost of purchasing the put, resulting in little or no net upfront cost. This strategy limits both potential losses and gains within a specified price range.

Loan modification is a change made to the terms of an existing loan by a lender. It may involve a reduction in the interest rate, an extension of the length of time for repayment, a different type of loan, or any combination of the three.

A change to the original terms of a loan, often made to help a borrower who is having difficulty making payments. This can include a lower interest rate, a longer repayment period, or a principal reduction.

A loan modification is a permanent change to the terms of an existing loan, typically made by a lender in response to a borrower's long-term inability to repay the loan under the original terms. Modifications may include reducing the interest rate, extending the repayment period, or changing the type of loan to make payments more affordable for the borrower.

An ASSET that has a life span of less than three years and which tends to be consumed immediately, e.g., food, clothing. Nondurable goods form part of the PERSONAL CONSUMPTION component of GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (and GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT). See also CAPITAL GOOD, DURABLE GOOD.
A consumer good that is used up or consumed relatively quickly, typically within three years, and has a short lifespan. Examples include food, beverages, and clothing.
A nondurable good is a consumer product that is used up or has a lifespan of less than three years, such as food, beverages, or toiletries, and must be purchased regularly due to its short-term use.

Key rate duration measures how the value of a debt security or a debt instrument portfolio, generally bonds,Â changes at a specific maturity point along the entirety of the yield curve. When keeping other maturities constant, the key rate duration is used to measure the sensitivity in a debt security's price to a 1% change in yield for a specific maturity.

A measure of a bond's or portfolio's sensitivity to changes in interest rates at specific points along the yield curve. It quantifies how much the value of an investment is expected to change if the interest rate at a particular maturity (e.g., 2-year, 5-year, 10-year) shifts, while other rates remain constant.

Key Rate Duration is a measure of a bond’s or portfolio’s sensitivity to changes in yield at a specific maturity point along the yield curve, holding yields at all other maturities constant. It helps investors assess interest rate risk exposure to shifts in particular segments of the yield curve.

In finance, â€œFAANGâ€ is an acronym that refers to the stocks of five prominent American technology companies: Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX); and Alphabet (GOOG) (formerly known as Google).

A group of five prominent American technology companies: Facebook (now Meta Platforms), Apple, Amazon, Netflix, and Google (now Alphabet). These stocks are known for their significant market capitalization, rapid growth, and influence on the broader stock market.

FAANG Stocks refer to the group of high-performing technology and internet companies: Facebook (now Meta Platforms), Apple, Amazon, Netflix, and Google (now Alphabet). These stocks are known for their significant market capitalization, strong growth potential, and substantial influence on the overall performance of the stock market, particularly within major indices like the S&P 500.

Counterparty risk is the likelihood or probability that one of those involved in a transaction might default on its contractual obligation. Counterparty risk can exist in credit, investment, and trading transactions.
The risk that a party to a financial contract will be unable to fulfill its obligations, leading to a potential financial loss for the other party.
Counterparty risk is the possibility that the other party in a financial transaction will default on its contractual obligations, leading to a financial loss for the non-defaulting party.

A unified tax credit is a certain amount of assets that each person is allowed to gift to other parties without having to pay gift, estate, or generation-skipping transfer taxes. The credit is afforded to every man, woman, and child in America by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

A tax credit that combines multiple existing tax credits into a single, more streamlined credit, often with the aim of simplifying the tax system, reducing administrative burden, or providing more comprehensive financial relief to eligible taxpayers. The specific credits unified can vary by jurisdiction and the design of the particular program.

A unified tax credit is a provision in U.S. tax law that combines the gift tax credit and the estate tax credit into a single credit, allowing individuals to transfer a certain amount of assets either during their lifetime or at death without incurring federal gift or estate taxes, up to a specified exemption limit set by the IRS.
